title: RL32730
content: On December 18, 2006, a U.S. commercial television station in Florida started broadcasting TV Marti programs daily. Radio Marti programming was also broadcasted by a Miami radio station. Cuban journalist Guillermo Fariñas Hernández received the 2006 Cyber Dissident award for his hunger strike demanding Internet access in Cuba. Dissident Hector Palacios was released from prison for health reasons after being sentenced to 25 years. Raúl offered to negotiate with the United States in a speech on December 2, 2006. In a December 2, 2006 speech, Raúl reiterated an offer to negotiate with the United States based on "equality, reciprocity, non-interference, and mutual respect." The Government Accountability Office (GAO) issued a report on U.S. democracy assistance for Cuba from 1996-2005, highlighting significant problems. Assistant Secretary of State Thomas Shannon reiterated a U.S. offer to lift economic sanctions if Cuba began a political opening and transition to democracy. Raúl Castro expressed Cuba's willingness to normalize relations in an interview on August 18, 2006. On August 18, 2006, Raúl Castro expressed Cuba's willingness to normalize relations with the U.S. but criticized current U.S. policy as "arrogant and interventionist." John Negroponte announced the creation of a Mission Manager for Cuba and Venezuela in the Intelligence Community. Fidel Castro's recovery after surgery was indicated to be lengthy. Condoleezza Rice encouraged positive change in Cuba, and President Bush reiterated U.S. support. On August 3, 2006, President Bush reiterated U.S. support for democratic change in Cuba. Cuban President Fidel Castro temporarily ceded power to his brother Raúl due to surgery. Raúl Castro assumed key leadership roles in Cuba. The House Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere held a hearing on assistance to a Free Cuba. The Senate Appropriations Committee reported on FY2007 Transportation/Treasury. The Senate Appropriations Committee reported its version of the FY2007 Transportation/Treasury appropriations bill, H.R. 5576, with a provision to prevent Treasury Department funds from being used to implement tightened restrictions on financing for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. The inter-agency Commission for Assistance to Free Cuba issued its second report with recommendations for political change in Cuba, including $80 million for democracy projects. The report received a mixed response from Cuba's dissident community. The House passed H.R. 5672, the FY2007 Science, State, Justice, Commerce and Related Agencies appropriations bill, funding Cuba broadcasting. The bill recommends $36.102 million for Cuba broadcasting, including $2.7 million for TV Marti. The Senate Appropriations Committee reported H.R. 5384, the FY2007 Agriculture appropriations bill, with a provision liberalizing travel to Cuba for agricultural and medical goods. On June 14, 2006, the House approved H.Amdt. 1049 to prevent Treasury Department funds from implementing tightened restrictions on financing for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. The House rejected amendments easing economic sanctions on Cuba, including H.Amdt. 1050 and H.Amdt. 1051. Another rejected amendment, H.Amdt. 1032, aimed to prohibit the use of funds to amend regulations related to Cuba. The State Department reported that the Cuban government cut off electricity to the U.S. Interests Section in Havana as a form of harassment towards U.S. diplomats, but electricity was restored the next day. The Senate passed a resolution condemning the beating of a Cuban dissident, and two Cuban dentists were released from a detention center in the Bahamas and taken into U.S. custody. The Cuban government denied exit visas to two dentists who had received U.S. visas while in Cuba. The Treasury Department asked a hotel in Mexico City to expel a Cuban delegation meeting with U.S. oil executives at an energy conference. Mexico fined the hotel $112,000 for complying with U.S. economic sanctions against Cuba. OFAC blocked retail services like hotel stays for Cuban nationals outside the U.S. La Estrella de Cuba, a major travel agency, was suspended from booking travel to Cuba. Major League Baseball was granted a license for a Cuban team to participate in a tournament in the U.S. to benefit hurricane victims. On January 9, 2006, the U.S. Coast Guard repatriated 15 Cuban migrants that had landed on a piling of an old bridge in the Florida Keys. This prompted a review of the "wet foot/dry foot" policy. A federal judge in Miami ordered the U.S. government to bring the 15 Cubans back to the United States. On January 6, 2006, a Florida International University professor and his wife were arrested for being covert agents for Cuba. Fidel Castro ruled Cuba as a communist state until recently stepping down temporarily. Fidel Castro ruled Cuba as head of state and government since the 1959 Cuban Revolution, proclaiming himself a Marxist-Leninist in 1961. He ruled by decree until 1976 when a Constitution established the Communist Party as the leading force in the state. Executive power was held by a Council of Ministers headed by Castro, with legislative authority in a National Assembly of People's Power. The Cuban Communist Party reaffirmed its commitment to a single-party state during its 5th Congress in 1997, reelecting Fidel and Raúl Castro as first and second secretaries. Direct elections for the National Assembly were held in 1998 and 2003, but voters had no choice of candidates. Raúl Castro, Fidel's designated successor, was set to take over as head of state and government. Raúl Castro assumed political power temporarily from Fidel in 2006 due to Fidel's health issues. Fidel appointed Raúl as First Secretary of the Communist Party, Commander in Chief of the Revolutionary Armed Forces, and President of the Council of State and Government. Additionally, Fidel assigned other officials to key roles in health, education, and energy projects. Jose Ramon Machado Ventura and Esteban Lazo Hernandez, both members of the Politburo of the Communist Party and Vice Presidents of the Council of State, were appointed by Fidel Castro to key roles in managing funds for health, education, and energy programs. Celebrations for Fidel's 80th birthday were postponed to December 2, 2006, but he was unable to attend, sparking speculation about his health and return to power. Speculation surrounds Fidel Castro's health, with some believing he has cancer. There are differing opinions on the future of Cuba's communist government, with some predicting collapse upon Castro's departure and others pointing to a plan for his brother Raúl to succeed him. Observers have considered various scenarios for Cuba's future post-Castro. The future of Cuba's government post-Castro is uncertain, with potential scenarios including a successor communist government led by Raúl Castro, a military-led government, or a democratic transition. Raúl Castro is seen as the most likely successor due to his designation by Fidel and his leadership of the FAR, which controls the security apparatus and plays a significant role in the economy. A military-led government is considered a possibility only if the communist government fails due to internal divisions or instability. The future of Cuba's government post-Castro is uncertain, with potential scenarios including a successor communist government led by Raúl Castro, a military-led government, or a democratic transition. Despite hopes for a democratic transition, the Castro government has tightly controlled civil society, restricted human rights, and cracked down on dissent. Government attacks on human rights activists and dissidents in Cuba have persisted since the Pope's 1998 visit, with a severe crackdown in 2003. As of December 2006, 59 political prisoners from the "group of 75" remained incarcerated. The Cuban government, labeled as one of the world's worst human rights violators, controls all aspects of life through the Communist Party. The Cuban Commission on Human Rights reported 333 political prisoners at the end of 2005. The Cuban government held 333 political prisoners at the end of 2005, including 39 detainees without formal charges. The State Department report for 2005 highlighted numerous serious abuses, such as arbitrary arrests, denial of fair trials, abuse of detainees, harsh prison conditions, and restrictions on freedoms of speech and assembly. The government also maintained a pervasive surveillance system and retaliated against dissenters. The Cuban government retaliated against peaceful political change efforts, including the Varela Project. Despite allowing some opposition gatherings in 2005, dissent was suppressed through harassment, threats, and detention. Over 50 Cubans were detained for organizing or participating in demonstrations. Three individuals were informed of charges for undermining the government. The Ladies in White human rights group faced scrutiny. The Ladies in White (Damas de Blanco) received the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought from the European Parliament for their peaceful protests demanding the release of political prisoners in Cuba. Independent journalist Guillermo Fariñas Hernández received the 2006 Cyber Dissident award for his hunger strike advocating for broader Internet access in Cuba. The Cuban government cracked down on independent journalists, librarians, and democracy activists in 2003. Elizardo Sanchez, a human rights activist, heads the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation. In 2003, Elizardo Sanchez described the crackdown in Cuba as the most intense wave of repression in history. 75 activists, including journalists and democracy activists, were arrested, tried in summary trials, and sentenced to prison terms ranging from 6 to 28 years. Foreign journalists and diplomats were excluded from the trials. Notable activists sentenced included Raúl Rivero, Oscar Espinosa Chepe, Omar Rodríguez Saludes, Marta Beatriz Roque, Hector Palacios, and Luis Enrique Ferrer García. Oscar Elías Biscet, a prominent political prisoner, was also arrested after three years in prison. In April 2003, Cuban activist Oscar Elías Biscet was sentenced to 25 years in prison. The Cuban government executed three men who hijacked a ferry to reach the United States. Analysts suggest the crackdown on democracy activists was a response to perceived U.S. support for dissidents. The Cuban government's crackdown on opposition movements is seen as a message to deter U.S. support for dissidents and to strengthen political control amidst economic challenges. Some analysts believe the regime is clearing potential opposition to ensure a smooth succession to power for Raúl Castro. The government's actions indicate a serious security threat perception towards the dissident movement. The Cuban government's crackdown on opposition movements is viewed as a serious security threat. Some believe that the government took harsh action to prevent any easing of the embargo under the Bush Administration. In 2004, 14 political prisoners were released for health reasons, including economist Marta Beatriz Roque. In late 2004, the Cuban government released seven prisoners, including prominent figures like Raúl Rivero and Oswaldo Alfonso Valdes, in a move seen as an attempt to improve relations with Europe. However, the prisoners were only released on parole, leading to concerns from human rights groups like Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International. The Varela Project, named after Felix Varela, aims to gather support for political reform through a national plebiscite. The Varela Project, led by Oswaldo Payá, gathered thousands of signatures for a national plebiscite in Cuba, calling for political reform, respect for human rights, amnesty for political prisoners, private enterprise, and electoral law changes for free and fair elections. Over 11,000 signatures were submitted to the National Assembly, surpassing the required 10,000. Former President Jimmy Carter highlighted the project's significance in a 2002 address in Havana. The Varela Project, led by Oswaldo Payá, aimed to bring political reform to Cuba through a national plebiscite. Despite government crackdowns, Payá continued his efforts, including delivering signatures to the National Assembly and initiating the National Dialogue for democratic transition. Thousands of Cubans have participated in discussions on democratic reforms. A group of Cuban activists met to discuss a transition program document covering various themes like economic, political, social issues, and reconciliation with the exile community. Led by prominent human rights activists, the Assembly to Promote Civil Society held meetings in Havana in 2005. Despite some restrictions, the meeting was significant as it coincided with Cuba's independence day. The Assembly of Cuban dissidents issued a ten-point resolution at a meeting in Havana, calling for political and economic change in Cuba. The resolution included demands for the release of political prisoners, respect for human rights, abolition of the death penalty, and endorsement of a dissident document on political and economic rights. In the 109th Congress, resolutions were passed urging Cuba to release political prisoners, legalize political parties and unions, and hold free elections. In the 109th Congress, resolutions were passed urging Cuba to release political prisoners, legalize political parties and unions, and hold free and fair elections. Additionally, resolutions expressed support for the Assembly to Promote Civil Society in Cuba and called for the international community to support its mission to bring democracy to the country. In the 109th Congress, resolutions were passed urging Cuba to release political prisoners, legalize political parties and unions, and hold free and fair elections. S.Res. 469 (Lieberman) condemns the beating and intimidation of Cuban dissident Martha Beatriz Roque in 2006. House subcommittees held a hearing on Cuba's human rights crackdown in 2005. Congress funds democracy and human rights projects for Cuba in annual appropriations measures. Cuba experienced severe economic deterioration from 1989-1993, with estimates of decline ranging from 35-50%. Economic growth averaged 3.7% annually from 1994-2000, with a high of 7.8% in 1996. Economic growth slowed in 2001 and 2002 due to Hurricane Michelle and the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Cuba's tourist industry was severely affected, with reports of hotel closures and empty restaurants. Hurricane Michelle damaged around 45,000 homes. Hurricanes caused significant damage in Cuba, with economic growth affected by drought and storms. In 2005, despite Hurricane Dennis and Wilma, growth reached 9.5%. Dennis killed 16 people and caused $1.4 billion in damages, while Wilma led to flooding in Havana and $700 million in damage. Cuba's economy was impacted by hurricanes causing damage, but economic growth benefited from tourism, nickel, and oil sectors. The country has a preferential oil agreement with Venezuela and promises of Chinese investment to boost nickel production. Cuba takes pride in achievements in health and education, with high literacy and life expectancy rates. The government began adopting market-oriented economic reforms in 1993 after facing economic decline. Cuba implemented economic reforms in 1993, allowing Cubans to use U.S. dollars, engage in self-employment, and open markets for agriculture and handicrafts. These reforms aimed to boost the economy and attract foreign investment. In 1995, Cuba approved a new foreign investment law allowing fully owned investments by foreigners in most sectors, established free trade zones in 1996, and reformed the banking system in 1997. Despite these measures, many Cubans still face challenges such as low wages, high prices, shortages of goods, and power outages. The government has also backtracked on some reform efforts, making it difficult for self-employed individuals and causing some businesses to close. Foreign investors have complained about the government reneging on deals. In April 2004, the Cuban government limited the use of dollars by state companies for non-core services. Fidel Castro announced in October 2004 that U.S. dollars would no longer be accepted in entities like stores and restaurants. Cubans had to exchange dollars for convertible pesos with a 10% surcharge. Dollar bank accounts could still be used, but new deposits were not allowed. By April 2005, convertible pesos were no longer equal to the U.S. dollar. In April 2004, the Cuban government limited the use of dollars by state companies. By October 2004, U.S. dollars were no longer accepted in stores and restaurants, leading to the use of convertible pesos with a 10% surcharge. By April 2005, convertible pesos were no longer on par with the U.S. dollar, affecting dollar remittances to Cuba. The U.S.-Cuban relationship has been marked by hostility, including covert operations, the Bay of Pigs invasion, the Cuban missile crisis, and Cuban support for insurgencies in Africa and the Western Hemisphere. Since the early 1960s, U.S. policy towards Cuba has involved isolating the nation through economic sanctions, strengthened by the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996. Key events include the Mariel boatlift in 1980, the 1994 exodus of Cubans to Guantanamo and Panama, and the 1996 shootdown of U.S. civilian planes by Cuban fighter jets. The Helms/Burton legislation, enacted in response to Cuba's shooting down of two U.S. civilian planes in 1996, imposes sanctions on vessels engaged in trade with Cuba and holds those trafficking in U.S. confiscated property liable for damages. Presidents Clinton and Bush have suspended the implementation of certain provisions, while U.S. policy also includes support measures for the Cuban people such as humanitarian donations and medical exports. The U.S. policy towards Cuba includes humanitarian donations, medical exports, democracy-building support, radio and television broadcasting, and agricultural exports with restrictions. Changes were made after the Pope's 1998 visit to support the Cuban people, such as resuming direct flights and cash remittances for close relatives. In response to the migration crisis with Cuba in August 1994, measures were taken to streamline procedures for the commercial sale of medical supplies. President Clinton announced additional measures in January 1999, including broadening cash remittances to Cuba for all U.S. residents, expanding direct passenger charter flights from more U.S. cities, and loosening travel restrictions for certain categories of travelers. The Bush Administration continued the policy of isolating Cuba economically. The Bush Administration continued the policy of isolating Cuba economically through sanctions and supporting the Cuban people. Tightening restrictions on travel, remittances, and humanitarian aid to Cuba were emphasized. President Bush stated in 2001 that sanctions would remain until Cuba meets certain conditions for political freedom. President Bush announced measures to support democratic change in Cuba, including enhancing enforcement capabilities, facilitating humanitarian assistance, providing direct aid through NGOs, resuming direct mail service, and establishing scholarships. President Bush announced measures to support democratic change in Cuba, including enhancing enforcement capabilities, facilitating humanitarian assistance, resuming direct mail service, and establishing scholarships for Cuban students and professionals. He stated that full normalization of relations would only occur when Cuba had a fully democratic government, respected the rule of law, and protected human rights. The President also emphasized that economic sanctions and the ban on travel to Cuba would continue until Cuba's government showed commitment to real reform. The President announced initiatives to hasten the arrival of a new, free, democratic Cuba, including increasing inspections, improving immigration processes, and establishing a Commission for Assistance to a Free Cuba. The Bush Administration took measures in 2004 to tighten U.S. policies towards Cuba. In 2004, the Bush Administration tightened U.S. sanctions against Cuba by expanding policing of waters, denying visas to Cubans involved in "show trials," and endorsing recommendations from the Commission for Assistance to a Free Cuba. President Bush allocated up to $59 million for these efforts. In 2004, the Bush Administration tightened U.S. sanctions against Cuba by implementing key recommendations from the Commission for Assistance to a Free Cuba, including support for democracy-building activities and airborne broadcasts to Cuba. The report also recommended tightening economic sanctions on family visits, travel, and humanitarian assistance. Subsequent regulations were issued to implement these sanctions. In 2005, the Administration further restricted how U.S. agricultural exporters could be paid for their sales. In July 2005, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice appointed Caleb McCarry as the State Department's new Cuba Transition Coordinator to direct U.S. government actions in support of a free Cuba. The Commission for Assistance to Free Cuba issued its second report in July 2006, calling for the United States to provide $80 million over two years to support Cuban civil society and fund education programs and exchanges. The Commission for Assistance to Free Cuba recommended funding of $10 million for university training in Cuba, $24 million to break the information blockade, and $15 million for civil society support. They also suggested an annual funding of at least $20 million for democracy programs until the dictatorship ends. The Commission for Assistance to Free Cuba outlined detailed plans for U.S. government assistance to a Cuba transition government, including humanitarian aid, free elections, and a market-based economy. Preparatory steps were recommended to be taken before Cuba's transition begins. The report received a mixed response from Cuba's dissident community. Some Cuban dissidents expressed concerns about the Commission's report, emphasizing the need for Cubans to solve their own problems without outside interference. Miriam Leiva of the Ladies in White criticized the report for potentially providing the government with reasons to imprison dissidents and for presuming what a Cuban transition should entail before receiving U.S. recognition or assistance. Leiva stressed that only Cubans should decide on such important matters. President Bush expressed strong support for the Cuban people's desire for democracy and freedom following Fidel Castro's announcement of ceding power to his brother Raúl. The United States pledged assistance in building a transitional government in Cuba and reiterated its commitment to supporting peaceful democratic change in the country. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice also emphasized U.S. support for Cubans seeking democratic reforms. The United States supports peaceful democratic change in Cuba and has plans to respond to any potential migration crisis. Secretary of State Rice encouraged positive change in Cuba, while Homeland Security officials announced measures to discourage risky sea travel. Raúl Castro expressed willingness to normalize relations but opposed current policies. Raúl Castro expressed willingness to normalize relations with the United States but opposed current U.S. policy towards Cuba as "arrogant and interventionist." The Bush Administration offered to lift economic sanctions if Cuba made political reforms, including freeing political prisoners and respecting human rights. Raúl reiterated an offer to negotiate with the United States to resolve longstanding disputes. Raúl Castro expressed willingness to resolve the longstanding dispute between the United States and Cuba through negotiations, based on principles of equality, reciprocity, non-interference, and mutual respect. The Bush Administration established interagency working groups to manage U.S. policy towards Cuba, focusing on diplomatic actions, strategic communications, democratic promotion, and humanitarian aid in the event of a democratic transition government. The government requests assistance in managing U.S. policy towards Cuba. The Department of Homeland Security and the National Security Council lead a working group on migration. The U.S. Director of National Intelligence established a Mission Manager for Cuba and Venezuela to integrate intelligence collection and analysis. Different schools of thought exist on how to achieve the objective of promoting democracy and human rights in Cuba. Advocates for a shift in U.S. policy towards Cuba propose lifting sanctions to promote dialogue and peaceful change, emphasizing the need to avoid violent upheaval and mass migration. They argue for increased engagement through travel, trade, and diplomacy to encourage reform in Cuba. Advocates for changing U.S. policy towards Cuba suggest lifting sanctions to promote peaceful dialogue and reform, emphasizing the importance of engagement through travel, trade, and diplomacy. They argue for a more realistic approach to induce change in Cuba, citing international support for lifting the embargo, missed business opportunities, and increased suffering of the Cuban people. Opponents maintain that the current two-track policy of isolating Cuba while supporting the Cuban people is the best way to achieve political change. The Solidarity Act of 1996 outlines steps for Cuba to take for the U.S. to normalize relations, including lifting the embargo. Opponents argue that softening U.S. policy without Cuban reforms would benefit the Castro regime. They believe sustained sanctions can work and that Cuba's economic decline is due to failed policies, not the embargo. Fidel Castro's temporary transfer of power to his brother in 2006 could impact the situation. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 codifies existing embargo provisions without a presidential waiver, impacting U.S. policy towards Cuba. Fidel Castro's temporary transfer of power to his brother in 2006 could influence U.S. policy towards Cuba. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 imposes restrictions on U.S. policy towards Cuba, including the ability to sue for damages related to confiscated property. The President can delay implementation for six months if it serves the national interest and aids in Cuba's transition to democracy. President Clinton utilized this provision in 1996 to postpone lawsuits against those benefiting from confiscated U.S. property in Cuba. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 allows for the filing of lawsuits against those benefiting from confiscated U.S. property in Cuba. President Clinton initially suspended the implementation of Title III, citing the need for a transition to democracy in Cuba. Subsequent presidents continued to suspend the right to file lawsuits at six-month intervals. President Bush suspended Title III implementation in July 2001, citing efforts by U.S. allies for democratic change in Cuba. Assistant Secretary of State Roger Noriega justified the continued suspension in 2003 due to countries condemning Cuba for human rights violations. Title IV denies entry to the U.S. for those involved in confiscating U.S. property in Cuba. The State Department has banned executives and their families from three companies for investing in confiscated U.S. property in Cuba. The provision is mandatory but can be waived on a case-by-case basis for humanitarian or legal reasons. Grupos Domos, Sherritt International, and BM Group are among the companies affected. Executives of STET, an Italian telecommunications company, paid $25 million to ITT Corporation for the use of U.S.-claimed property in Cuba. Sol Melia, a Spanish hotel company, was investigated for investing in confiscated property in Cuba but settlement efforts failed. Jamaica's SuperClubs resort chain decided to disinvest from Cuban hotels due to potential denial of U.S. entry for top officials. The enactment of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act in May led to strong criticism from U.S. allies like Canada, Japan, Mexico, and EU nations. The law allowed foreign persons to be sued in U.S. court, which was seen as an extraterritorial application of U.S. law. However, U.S. officials defended the law citing rights under NAFTA and WTO. A settlement was reached between the EU and U.S. on April 11, 1997, regarding the extraterritorial application of U.S. law. The EU-U.S. understanding on promoting democracy in Cuba and investment protection was reached on April 11, 1997. The EU suspended its WTO dispute settlement case and later let its challenge expire in mid-April 1998. Talks on investment disciplines were challenging, but a second understanding was reached on May 18, 1998, outlining EU disciplines on investment. The EU-U.S. understanding on investment in expropriated properties was established on May 18, 1998. It set out disciplines prohibiting future investment in expropriated properties and denying government support for past illegal expropriations. A Registry of Claims would be created to alert investors and government agencies. Mixed reactions from Congress members followed, with opposition from senior members preventing any changes to Title IV. The Bush Administration initially supported the agreement. The Bush Administration's efforts to amend Title IV of the Helms/Burton legislation were hindered by Congress. In 2003, there were discussions of a potential agreement with the EU regarding Cuba policy in exchange for waiver authority for Title IV and Title III. Additionally, a dispute between Pernod Ricard and Bacardi Ltd. in the World Trade Organization involved the production and export of Havana Club rum. The FY1999 omnibus appropriations measure (Section 211 of Division A, title II, P.L. 105-277) prevents the United States from accepting payment for trademark registrations and renewals from Cuban or foreign nationals used in connection with confiscated assets in Cuba without the original owner's consent. Pernod Ricard's joint venture with the Cuban government to produce Havana Club rum faces challenges from Bacardi over the rights to the Havana Club name in the U.S. market. Pernod Ricard's joint venture under the Havana Club label faced legal challenges from Bacardi in the U.S. federal court over the use of the Havana Club name. The U.S. Court of Appeals ruled against the joint venture, leading to EU initiating WTO dispute settlement proceedings in 2000, citing violations of TRIPS agreement. WTO panel's ruling in August 2001 was mixed, with both sides claiming partial victory regarding U.S. law on intellectual property rights and trade names. The EU appealed a U.S. court ruling on Cuban trademarks to the WTO, which resulted in a mixed ruling in January 2002. The appellate panel upheld the U.S. position on trademark ownership criteria but found that Section 211 violated WTO provisions on national treatment and most-favored-nation treatment. The United States needed to amend Section 211 to comply with WTO rules on national treatment and most-favored-nation treatment. Despite access to courts for trademark rights enforcement, Section 211 discriminated against Cuban nationals and foreign successors-in-interest. The U.S. agreed to comply with the WTO ruling through legislative action by Congress by January 3, 2003, but the deadline was extended multiple times due to inaction. In a 2005 EU-U.S. agreement, the EU postponed retaliation authorization, while the U.S. agreed not to block future EU requests. Different approaches were proposed to bring Section 211 into WTO compliance. Advocates propose two approaches to address Section 211 compliance with the WTO ruling: amending it to include U.S. companies or repealing it altogether. The narrow fix would extend Section 211 to U.S. companies to prevent foreign compensation claims on U.S. property. Alternatively, repealing Section 211 is advocated to protect trademarks of over 500 U.S. companies in Cuba. The Senate Judiciary Committee discussed this issue in the 108th Congress. In the 108th and 109th Congress, various legislative initiatives were proposed to repeal Section 211 trademark provision, but no action was taken. Bills such as H.R. 3372 and S. 1604 aimed to repeal Section 211, while others like H.R. 208 and H.R. 579 included provisions to lift the overall embargo and repeal Section 211. Additionally, bills like H.R. 719 and S. 328, which aimed to facilitate U.S. agricultural sales to Cuba, also included provisions to repeal Section 211. The proposed amendment to the FY2006 and FY2007 Foreign Affairs Authorization Act included a provision to repeal Section 211. Two bills, S. 691 and H.R. 1689, aimed to amend Section 211 to apply to U.S. companies. The EU-U.S. bilateral agreement in July 2005 reduced pressure on Congress to comply with the WTO ruling. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 allowed for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba with restrictions. The Trade Sanctions Reform Act of 2000 (TSRA) allows for one-year export licenses for selling agricultural commodities to Cuba, but no U.S. government assistance or financing is available. Transactions must be conducted in cash in advance or with financing from third countries. TSRA also authorizes travel to Cuba for business related to agricultural sales. Regulations were published in 2001, and in 2004, U.S. banks were instructed to stop transfers of funds for sales to Cuba. OFAC temporarily halted sales of agricultural and medical products to Cuba to investigate potential violations of the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. They later clarified that "payment of cash in advance" means receiving payment before shipment. New regulations were implemented on March 24, 2005, causing concerns among U.S. agricultural exporters and some Members of Congress. OFAC clarified that for the commercial sale of U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba, vessels can leave U.S. ports once a foreign bank confirms receipt of payment from Cuba. This action aims to protect goods from seizure for unrelated claims while still at the U.S. port. Supporters of overturning OFAC's previous amendment are pleased with the clarification but still plan to work towards overturning the rule. Cuba has purchased over $1.4 billion in agricultural products from the U.S. since late 2001. Overall, U.S. exports to Cuba saw fluctuations in the early 2000s, with a significant increase in 2004 followed by a decline in 2005. The Cuban government attributed the decrease to stricter U.S. regulations, while others believed it was due to Cuba's lobbying efforts. The rebound in exports in the second half of 2005 coincided with a clarification on payment terms by OFAC. Some groups advocate for easing restrictions on agricultural exports to Cuba, citing harm to Cuban population's health and nutrition. U.S. agribusiness companies support lifting restrictions to access a market worth over $700 million annually. They argue that allowing financing for agricultural exports would benefit smaller U.S. companies expanding purchases to Cuba. Opponents of easing restrictions on agricultural exports to Cuba argue that U.S. policy already allows sales to Cuba, citing large sales since 2001. They believe that supporting such exports would prolong the Castro regime and its repressive policies. Some agricultural producers support the prohibition on financing for exports to ensure payment. In the 109th Congress, attention was on overturning Treasury Department regulations regarding "payments of cash in advance" for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. The House Agriculture Committee held a hearing on this issue, and both the House and Senate passed provisions in the FY2006 Treasury appropriations bill to prevent the implementation of tighter restrictions on these payments. In the 109th Congress, there was a focus on overturning Treasury Department regulations regarding "payments of cash in advance" for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. The Administration threatened to veto any bill containing such a provision. Ultimately, the provision was not included in the final conference report. Press reports indicated that the White House rejected language that would have denied funds to the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control. In the second session of the 109th Congress, both the House and Senate versions of the FY2007 Transportation/Treasury appropriation bill contained a provision similar to the one approved in 2005. In the 109th Congress, provisions were added to prevent the implementation of tightened restrictions on financing for U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. The House provision was added by H.Amdt. 1049 (Moran, Kansas), while the Senate provision was added by an amendment offered by Senator Dorgan. Final action on FY2007 Transportation/Treasury appropriations was not completed by the end of the Congress. The FY2007 Agriculture appropriations bill, H.R. 5384 (S.Rept. 109-266), included a provision (Section 755) to ease travel to Cuba for the sale of agricultural and medical goods. Legislation introduced in the 109th Congress aimed to clarify terms related to the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act (TSRA). The bills introduced in the 109th Congress aimed to ease travel restrictions for the sale of agricultural products to Cuba and included provisions for general licenses for travel transactions. Proposed amendments sought to facilitate the entry of Cuban nationals for purchasing U.S. agricultural commodities. Additionally, some bills proposed lifting the overall embargo on Cuba. The bills introduced in the 109th Congress aimed to lift the overall embargo on Cuba, including restrictions on agricultural trade and travel. Restrictions on travel to Cuba have been a contentious issue for the past 40 years, with changes over time. Enforcement of travel restrictions increased under the Bush Administration, with tighter restrictions on travel and remittances to Cuba. In June 2004, the Bush Administration significantly restricted travel to Cuba, especially family visits and private humanitarian assistance in the form of remittances and gift parcels. Family visits are now limited to one trip every three years for immediate family members, with cash remittances further restricted to quarterly amounts of $300 for immediate family only. The regulations for remittances and gift parcels to Cuba have been tightened.
